data.title: The Mile High Team That Always Falls Short
data.meta_description: In 2013, during a Denver Nuggets home game, the team’s mascot was being rappelled down into the center of the arena before unexpectedly passing out and helplessly dangling in front of perplexed fans…
data.text:
In 2013, during a Denver Nuggets home game, the team’s mascot was being rappelled down into the center of the arena before unexpectedly passing out and helplessly dangling in front of perplexed fans. It was an accident, of course, and epitomized how any moment of excitement can quickly turn into disaster, even on a basketball court. It’s something Denver fanatics are used to by now. More than once or twice, this fanbase has watched a potentially celebratory situation unravel into inevitable disappointment. Most recently, after losing to the Los Angeles Lakers in the Western Conference Finals, it seems that the team has once again failed to keep their breath.

Despite being praised as the resilient underdogs of the Bubble Playoffs, Denver has unfortunately reinforced their status as the most consistently short-fallen contenders in modern basketball— an organization that has regularly built winning teams with talented players since the ‘70s without actually appearing in a single Finals series. For decades, Denver has admirably assembled these competitive rosters with Mile High expectations — only to flug it all up in the playoffs against teams that just know how to…
